entry.title: Sweden Expands Anti-Sex Work Law to Criminalize Paying for Custom OnlyFans Clips and Camming
entry.summary: The Nordic Model criminalizes buyers of sex in multiple European countries (and Maine). Sweden just voted to expand its reach to the internet.

entry.title: Kids Say They're Using Photos of Trump and Markiplier to Bypass 'Gorllia Tag' Age Verification
entry.summary: Popular VR game Gorilla Tag partnered with the company k-ID to comply with age verification laws.

entry.title: For Algorithms, a Little Memory Outweighs a Lot of Time
entry.summary: One computer scientist’s “stunning” proof is the first progress in 50 years on one of the most famous questions in computer science. The post For Algorithms, a Little Memory Outweighs a Lot of Time first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: Researchers Scrape 2 Billion Discord Messages and Publish Them Online
entry.summary: A Brazilian team used Discord’s API to scrape 10% of its open servers.

entry.title: Podcast: AI Slop Summer
entry.summary: How the Chicago Sun-Times printed an AI-generated summer guide; how schools were not prepared for ChatGPT; and those funny little guys from Star Wars.

entry.title: Scientists Explain Why Trump's $175 Billion Golden Dome Is a Fantasy
entry.summary: Shooting missiles out of the sky from space could require a constellation of 36,000 satellites.

entry.title: Viral AI-Generated Summer Guide Printed by Chicago Sun-Times Was Made by Magazine Giant Hearst
entry.summary: The Chicago Sun-Times said "we understand this is unacceptable for us to distribute."

entry.title: Civitai, Site Used to Generate AI Porn, Cut Off by Credit Card Processor
entry.summary: Civitai, a huge platform for sharing AI models and generating videos and images, has been cut off from its payment processor.

entry.title: Chicago Sun-Times Prints AI-Generated Summer Reading List With Books That Don't Exist
entry.summary: "I can't believe I missed it because it's so obvious. No excuses," the writer said. "I'm completely embarrassed."

entry.title: 'Configuration Issue' Allows Civitai Users to AI Generate Nonconsensual Porn Videos
entry.summary: 404 Media found that people were using Civitai to create nonconsensual AI porn videos of anyone for a small price.

entry.title: Telegram Gave Authorities Data on More than 20,000 Users
entry.summary: According to its newest transparency report, Telegram complied with more than 5,000 requests from authorities in the first three months of 2025.

entry.title: 23andMe Sale Shows Your Genetic Data Is Worth $17
entry.summary: 23andMe sold the genetic data of 15 million people for $256 million to a pharmaceutical company called Regeneron.

entry.title: Kansas Mom Sues Porn Sites Because Her Son Visited Chaturbate 30 Times
entry.summary: The 14 year old's mother left an old laptop in a closet and now alleges it's adult sites' problem that he watched porn.

entry.title: Keeping Ahead of Contagion
entry.summary: We have the technology to detect airborne pathogens in real time. Now we must use it.

entry.title: ‘Turbocharged’ Mitochondria Power Birds’ Epic Migratory Journeys
entry.summary: Slight changes in the number, shape, efficiency and interconnectedness of organelles in the cells of flight muscles provide extra energy for birds’ continent-spanning feats. The post ‘Turbocharged’ Mitochondria Power Birds’ Epic Migratory Journeys first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: Student Makes Tool That Identifies ‘Radicals’ on Reddit, Deploys AI Bots to Engage With Them
entry.summary: The tool scans for users writing certain keywords on Reddit and assigns those users a so-called “radical score,” before deploying an AI-powered bot to automatically engage with the users to de-radicalize them.

entry.title: The Universe Will Decay a Lot Sooner than Expected
entry.summary: This week, we have stories about wild horses, wild chimps, and wild cosmic deaths.

entry.title: Behind the Blog: The Art of the 'Catharticle'
entry.summary: This week, we discuss Star Wars' weird little guys, catharticles, and spectacular views.

entry.title: New ‘Superdiffusion’ Proof Probes the Mysterious Math of Turbulence
entry.summary: Turbulence is a notoriously difficult phenomenon to study. Mathematicians are now starting to untangle it at its smallest scales. The post New ‘Superdiffusion’ Proof Probes the Mysterious Math of Turbulence first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: Model Organisms Are Not Static
entry.summary: A research study reveals that some vertebrate genomes mutate 40-times faster than others.

entry.title: How Did Geometry Create Modern Physics?
entry.summary: Geometry may have its origins thousands of years ago in ancient land surveying, but it has also had a surprising impact on modern physics. In the latest episode of The Joy of Why, Yang-Hui He explores geometry’s evolution and its future potential through AI. The post How Did Geometry Create Modern Physics? first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: How the Universe Differs From Its Mirror Image
entry.summary: From living matter to molecules to elementary particles, the world is made of “chiral” objects that differ from their reflected forms. The post How the Universe Differs From Its Mirror Image first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: Seven Wonders of Biology
entry.summary: A decades-old essay offers newfound appreciation for progress.

entry.title: How Much Information is in DNA?
entry.summary: Answering this question may seem straightforward, but actually requires an odyssey through information theory and molecular biology.

entry.title: Are you more likely to die on your birthday?
entry.summary: Are you more likely to die on your birthday? Yes.

entry.title: Making the Centrifuge
entry.summary: The modern centrifuge was first designed for milkfat separation in the dairy industry. Today, it is ubiquitous in research laboratories. To whom do we owe its astonishing versatility?

entry.title: A Brief History of GFP
entry.summary: How a chance discovery in bioluminescent jellyfish led to one of the most transformative tools in modern biology: green fluorescent protein.

entry.title: Traffic Fatalities Are a Choice
entry.summary: America’s roads are more dangerous than those of almost every country in the developed world. We know how to change that.

entry.title: Reports of the Death of California High-Speed Rail Have Been Greatly Exaggerated
entry.summary: Building a high-speed rail between Los Angeles and San Francisco was never going to be easy — but the critics who write it off are missing the real source of the project’s struggles.

entry.title: Can We Trust Social Science Yet?
entry.summary: Everyone likes the idea of evidence-based policy, but it’s hard to realize it when our most reputable social science journals are still publishing poor quality research.

entry.title: Does AI Progress Have a Speed Limit?
entry.summary: A conversation about the factors that might slow down the pace of AI development, what could happen next, and whether we’ll be able to see it coming.

entry.title: China’s Clinical Trial Boom
entry.summary: In 2017, there were just over 600 clinical trials initiated in China. By 2023, that number was nearly 2,000. How can American companies kick off a similar boom?

entry.title: New Digital Collection Preserves Key Books on Drug Use and Policy
entry.summary: For many years, the Drug Policy Alliance (DPA) maintained a large library of books on drug use and policy at its New York City headquarters. As researchers shifted to working […]
